name: Alabama
policy: No post-election auditing practices.

name: Alaska
policy: Mandatory hand count of one randomly selected precinct in each of its 40 house districts that accounts for at least 5% of votes in the district. A discrepancy of more than 1% requires a hand recount of the entire district. Audit does not include UOCAVA ballots.

name: Arizona
policy: Hand count in at least 2% or 2 precincts in each county, whichever is greater, randomly selected. Can escalate to reverse preliminary outcome. Parties must designate two election board workers for the audit to take place—that requirement has been met consistently by all counties.

name: Arkansas
policy: No post-election auditing practices.

name: California
policy: Mandatory hand count of 1% of precincts in each county, randomly selected. Counties may choose to perform an RLA with a 5% risk limit. No audits of ballots received before or after electiond day.

name: Colorado
policy: Mandatory risk-limiting (ballot-level comparison in most counties) audit at a risk limit of 5%. Can reverse preliminary outcomes. There is a 1% risk limit for comparison audits in the 2020 Presidential Elections.

name: Connecticut
policy: Mandatory hand count of 5% of voting precincts, randomly selected.

name: Delaware
policy: Hand count the results from 1 randomly selectd voting device in each county. If the discrepency is more than 0.5% then all documentation related to the voting machine in question is to be reviewed by audit team and another voting machine from that county is radnomly audited.

name: District of Columbia
policy: Mandatory hand count of 5% of precincts and 5% of centrally tabulated votes. Can escalate to reverse preliminary outcomes if error rates are greater than .25%.

name: Florida
policy: Manually audit at least 1% of ballots in no more than 2% of precincts, or automated audit of all ballots in 20% of precincts.

name: Georgia
policy: Currently piloting RLA. To be mandatory after November 2020.

name: Hawaii
policy: Mandatory hand count in 10% of precincts, randomly selected.

name: Idaho
policy: No mandatory post-election auditing practices.

name: Illinois
policy: Audit in 5% of precincts in each county—the audit is permitted to be conducted electronically through retabulation or rescans which makes it vulnerable to hacking.

name: Indiana
policy: No mandatory post-election audit. Piloting RLA's before 2020 elections. Audits can be requested by either political party’s county chairman and would consist of either 5% or 5 precincts whichever is larger. The use of paperless DRE machines in many counties undermines any auditing capabilities. Conducted a risk-limiting audit pilot in Marion county (which uses paper ballots) during the 2018 primary.

name: Iowa
policy: Policy: Mandatory hand count. State comissioner determines number of precincts.

name: Kansas
policy: Mandatory hand count in 1% of precincts in each county—precincts randomly selected. However, the continued use of paperless voting machines in some jurisdictions will hamper the effectiveness of the audit.

name: Kentucky
policy: State conducts mandatory post-election “audits” in 5% of counties. These audits consist of interviewing county election officials and reviewing various forms. They have a law on the books that would conduct an audit to confirm the accuracy of election results but they don’t seem to use it.

name: Louisiana
policy: No post-election auditing practices.

name: Maine
policy: No post-election auditing practices.

name: Maryland
policy: Mandatory hand count of at least 2% of precincts. Mandatory post-election audits in 5% of all precincts, randomly selected. Audits consist of using software to inspect ballot images for discrepancies—this is subject to hacking and is not a robust system.

name: Massachusetts
policy: Mandatory hand count following presidential elections in 3% of all precincts, randomly selected.

name: Michigan
policy: Passed ballot proposal in 2018 to require post-election audits. Unclear how it will be implemented—in the past it has audited 300 out of 4800 precincts. Currently piloting the largest known RLA implementation.

name: Minnesota
policy: Mandatory hand count of precincts in each county. Can escalate to reverse preliminary outcomes. The number of precincts to be audited varies by the number of registered voters in the county: • In a county with fewer than 50,000 registered voters, a total of at least 2 precincts must be audited.• In a county with between 50,000 and 100,000 registered voters, a total of at least 3 precincts must be audited.• In a county with more than 100,000 registered voters at least 4 precincts, or 3% of all precincts, whichever is greater, must be audited.

name: Mississippi
policy: No post-election auditing practices.

name: Missouri
policy: Mandatory hand count of 5% of all precincts, randomly selected.

name: Montana
policy: Mandatory hand count in 1 precinct or 5% of precincts, whichever is greater, randomly selected, in each county that uses ballot tabulators (counties that hand count ballots do not need to audit).

name: Nebraska
policy: If secretary of state asks for it, the state randomly selects between two and two and a half percent of precincts to be tested. Votes cast in one federal race, one state race and one local race are hand counted and compared to the machine tabulations for the same races in those precincts.

name: Nevada
policy: Piloting RLA for the 2020 general elections. All counties will have to conduct mandatory RLA's in 2022. Risk limit is unclear.

name: New Hampshire
policy: No post-election auditing practices.

name: New Jersey
policy: Mandatory audit of 2% of election districts. Audits must ensure with at least 99% confidence that a 100% manual recount would not change the result. An RLA pilot was conducted in Jan 2020.

name: New Mexico
policy: Language in law calls for an audit that ensures with 90% probability that “faulty tabulators” would be detected if they changed the outcome of an election. Unclear if the current procedure truly achieves that—Philip Stark pointed out a number of issues including the audit “hardwiring” sample sizes.

name: New York
policy: Mandatory audit of 3% of voting machines in each county. Audit can be either a hand count or electronic retabulation.

name: North Carolina
policy: Mandatory manual hand count of a number of randomly selected precincts determined in a consultation with a statistician.

name: North Dakota
policy: No post-election auditing practices.

name: Ohio
policy: Audits are not codified in law, but Secretary of State (SOS) traditionally mandates a hand count of at least 5% of ballots in each county, randomly selected. SOS recommends counties conduct risk-limiting audits, but not required. The Ohio Election Initiative hopes to make it mandatory to audit some sample of all elections by November 2020. RLA is recommended but not mandated by the secretary of state.

name: Oklahoma
policy: No post-election auditing practices.

name: Oregon
policy: Mandatory audit of 3-10% of all precincts with 150 or more ballots (depending on margin of victory). Counties can conduct RLA if they choose. Reverse outcome if discrpency is larger than 0.5%.

name: Pennsylvania
policy: Requires a hand count or retabulation of 2% or 2000 votes, whichever is fewer, randomly selected in each county. Currently testing implementation of RLA in the state. Hope to have it fully implemented and ready for 2022 general election.

name: Rhode Island
policy: Mandatory RLA. Risk limit is unclear.

name: South Carolina
policy: No post-election auditing practices.

name: South Dakota
policy: No post-election auditing practices.

name: Tennessee
policy: No robust post-election auditing practices because paperless DRE machines are used in the state. In jurisdictions where paper ballots are used an audit is conducted using electronic retabulation.

name: Texas
policy: Mandatory hand count of 1% voting machines in the state or 3 non-paperless machines, with one coming from each county.

name: Utah
policy: Mandatory hand count of 1% of voting machines in the state, with one coming from each county.

name: Vermont
policy: Mandatory audit of 6 random towns to machine count ballots.

name: Virginia
policy: Every jurasdiction performs an audit once in 5 years. Audits follow a risk limitting process but cannot be truly risk limitting because not all ballots are subject to audit.

name: Washington
policy: Mandatory hand count or electronic retabulation of 4% or 1 DRE machine(s) with VVPR in each county, whichever is greater. Voluntary audit for counties who use paper ballots. Audits can escalate and affect preliminary outcomes. There are instructions on how to conduct RLA but unclear whether it is mandatory or not; election officials are 'allowed' to conduct RLA's.

name: West Virginia
policy: Mandatory hand count of 3% of precincts in each county, randomly selected. Can escalate to reverse preliminary outcome.

name: Wisconsin
policy: Mandatory hand count of 5% of all precincts, randomly selected. Cannot escalate to reverse preliminary outcome.

name: Wyoming
policy: No mandatory audit. Does not require VVPAT. Automatic recount when margin of victory is less than 1% of all votes for winner. Outdated voted machines.
